ï»¿Execution Version Dated October 9, 2014 L COLLABORATION ARRANGEMENT relating to Global Infrastructure Facility Partnership Program
ï»¿Execution Version This Collaboration Arrangement is entered into on October 9, 2014 between: (1) SWISS RE LTD, herein reprEsented by its Group Chief Investment Officer, Member of the Executive Committee, and hE adquartered at Mythenquai 50/60, 8022 Zurich, Switzerland " ;' iss Re"); and (2) THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT ("IBRD") and INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPI i r T ASSOCIATION ("IDA"), heac quartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 20433, Ur , he INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION, ("IFC") headquartered at 2121 Pennsylvar i;l Avenue, NW, Washington, D C 20433, USA, and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY, ("MIGA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 133, USA (the "World Bank Group") (each a "Party" and together the "Parties"). Preamble (A) There is broad internationa recognition, as confirmed by the G20, the OECD, Inter i;1t -nal Organizations (IOs), the G77, and the private sector represented by the B20 that investir ) ii the infrastructure of Emerging IVarkets and Developing Economies (EMDEs) is needed, to e: nd access to basic services and raise living standards for all, and to meet global economic (1r: vth targets. (B) Meeting this need presents a significant financing challenge. Given constraints on Jr::ing sources of infrastructure finance-particularly in the public sector-a redoubled and coo ar ted effort is needed to mobilize p-ivate sector finance for EMDE infrastructure. (C) There is an absence of robt st pipelines of structurally sound and bankable projects an I th 3 is understood to be the greates: barrier to achieving significantly more infrastructure investm . It (D) Governments, development Iinance institutions, donors, and private investors share an in rE t in developing the market for private infrastructure finance in EMDEs: both on the demand s c , in the numbers of structurally sound and bankable projects seeking finance, and gradual em ilg: ice of EMDE infrastructure as a recognized asset class; and the supply side, in the range o :ri 'ate investors that actively partic pate in financing those projects. Achieving these goals wil ;e iefit from collective action betwean this range of entities-to leverage resources and know: ! to find solutions to complex i1frastructure financing challenges that no single institutio,i c uld achieve alone. (E) In support of these goals, thE Parties propose the establishment of a Global InfrastructurE FE. ility Partnership Program ("GIF") The GIF will be an open global platform aiming at leveraiil' the efforts of the wide range of i istitutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastruct i=e vith the participation of private infrastructure investors, coalescing around project pree rm Ion, structuring, and risk mitigation for individual infrastructure investments. In this regard, t 3IF aims to complement existinj and proposed services and initiatives currently supportec :n the Parties and other prospective GIF partners. The GIF intends to provide resources to prep; r: /ell- structured, infrastructure prcjects, and to serve as an additional mechanism for acces ii ii: the expertise of the Parties and other GIF partners, in combination with guidance from pro :1E tive private sector financiers into project structures. The GIF thereby aims to achieve greater I: rE age of official resources in the fE ce of substantial EMDE infrastructure needs-in particular i rge and complex projects with th a potential to attract significant private capital. (F) The Parties are now interested in collaborating in developing the Global Infrastructure 1:,,ility Partnership Program, togeth -r with other partners. 2
ï»¿Execution Version Accordingly, the Parties have com. to the following understanding: 1 Global Infrastructure Facili-;y Partnership Program Framework 1.1 The GIF is intended io be based on the preliminary objectives and principles set o.i Annex 1 (Preliminary GIF Fo indational Principles). The Parties acknowledge their mutual understanding that while the 31F Foundational Principles are an initial basis for their colla oc r :ion, they are of an indicative natu,e and will continue to be developed amongst the Parties anc ,i: I other potential partners until he GIF is formally established. The final version of these obji c li, 3s and principles will be agreed upon by the GIF Partners and be reflected in the agreement establishing the GIF. 1.2 The Parties intend to work together with any additional participants who may be collaborating on the GIF to further enhance their coordination, in particular by developing t I IlF, with a view to formally establ shing the program by December 2014. 2 Further Collaboration 2.1 Pursuant to the foregoing, the Parties will use reasonable endeavors to continue t collaborate in developing the GIF, including but not limited to: a. Nature and scope of collaboration under the GIF, such as proposed categories of partnership and the r:les, rights, and responsibilities associated with each catego y b. Governance arrange nents of the GIF; c. Operational policies ipplicable to the GIF's operations; d. Scope of GIF activities and sources/uses of GIF funds, including approach to proji cI: selection criteria and coordination with the Parties' existing facilities; and e. Any other aspects of collaboration required to finalize the design of the GIF, incluc ir sharing best practice and experience with regard to project preparation, through tt Li e of knowledge platforms for the infrastructure sector. 2.2 During the process of finali; ing the design of the GIF, the multilateral development bani E Ii ted in Annex 2 will be invited lo participate as initial Technical Partners. Once the GIF d i: 1 is finalized, additional collabo ative efforts are required to develop the operational detailr or the GIF, at all times complementing existing efforts and facilities and building upon the 1 red knowledge and experience of the Parties in this area. This includes determining the E vi I of coordination between the Porties and project origination process. 3 General 3.1 This Collaboration Ar rangement is not a legally binding agreement or commitment Iy he Parties to enter into or provide support for any specific activity or project. The Parties acknowledge that the provisions of this Collaboration Arrangement represent their cornmc understanding and intentions only and that the Parties do not intend to create or impose a- gal obligations or liabilities on any Party. 3.2 This Collaboration Ai rangement is valid and effective for a period of one year fron h1 date thereof, unless superseded at an earlier date by the establishment of the GIF. 3.3 The Parties expect that this document and information with respect to the collabol : activities contemplated herei i will be publicly disclosed. Such disclosure will be made in accordance with the Parties' respective disclosure policies. The Parties plan to consult wit i e! ch 3
ï»¿Execution Version other concerning the manner and form of any acknowledgment of the other Party's suppoi regarding the activities. 3.4 Nothing in this arran(iement will constitute or be construed as a waiver, renunciati it other modification of any of the privileges, immunities and exemptions granted to any of th ) Parties under their constituer t documents, international conventions and any applicable la , : In witness whereof, each of the Par les has caused this Collaboration Arrangement to be execut c i two (2) counterparts of equal content and form by a duly authorized representative of each Party a ol the date first set forth above. 4
ï»¿Execution Version SWISS LTD. By: GUIDO FUERER, GROUP CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER 5
ï»¿Execution Version THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTIO Ifl ID DEVELOPMENT, the INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION, the INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY By: ON IM, PRESIDENT 6
ï»¿Execution Version Annex 1 Preliminary GIF Foundational Principles 1 Objectives 1.1 The objective of the 31F is to promote private sector investment in infrastructUre p (J: :ts in emerging markets and de% eloping economies (EMDEs) through robust project preparat:-I provision of appropriate risk mitigation instruments, and thereby increasing the commerci :ii institutional investor engagement in the EMDE infrastructure market. It is focused on collaboration in complex pub ic-private partnerships and projects with potential for comme cE viability which require project preparation resources, policy dialogue and eventual infrastrL c:L 3 financing solutions that no single institution could achieve alone. 1.2 To this end, the GIF aims to create a global platform to provide financial and coon i HI Ion resources in collaboration wi h the project preparation, advisory, and financing efforts of t: v, de range of donor and development finance institutions currently engaged in supporting EMO:: infrastructure, with the input and ideas of private infrastructure investors. GIF's engageme il ( uld stretch from upstream suppo I on project definition, preparation, and investment feasibility assessment, through to downstream transaction preparation, financial structuring, and risi mitigation/credit enhancemei it. 1.3 Over the longer term by contributing to the stock of high quality and well-structurE d infrastructure projects, the G F can be expected to help in the development of EMDE infrastructure as an asset class attractive to a wide range of private investors seeking lone . - n assets in faster growing ecor omies, but which until now have been presented only limited infrastructure investment oprortunities that meet their risk tolerance and investment p,ofilk 2 Operating Principles 2.1 The GIF intends to o)erate according to the following core principles, to be finalizi i. )on agreement among GIF partners: (i) Leveraging the private sector-specializing in project financing modalities ti at 'ill draw together ccmparative advantages of public and private sectors; (ii) Addressing public goods-focusing on core infrastructure; particularly thost infrastructure prcjects that are climate friendly or trade enabling; (iii) Promoting sustainability and inclusiveness-ensuring projects adhere to I Es: practice standards for social and environmental responsibility; and (iv) Collaborating, c omplementing and partnering for solutions-mobilizing tb c h ical and financial res)urces of all partner entities-World Bank Group entities, mu 1:i al ral development ins :itutions, other public institutions, and private investors-in ar innovative and fl 3xible way, to complement existing capacities, achieve great( r leverage and address the complex infrastructure financing challenges that arE beyond the reso irces of any individual partner. 3 Institutional Arrangements and Governance 3.1 The GIF is expected to involve a wide range of stakeholders who are involved in t 10 development and implementition of infrastructure projects, both public and private. GIF p r.r rs are expected to fall into one ,r more of the following categories: 7
ï»¿Execution Version (i) Funding Partners-Partners that provide financial contributions to the GIF wi I considered Fund ng Partners. (ii) Technical Partnirs-Partners that can and who will agree to provide specific technical advice ind support to GIF activities including execution of GIF-funde : activities and/or provision of GIF-backed credit enhancement or liquidity suppc r instruments. (iii) Advisory Partne rs-Private investors or entities that represent the voice of commercial and/or institutional investment, whether pension funds, insurance companies, sove-eign wealth funds, banks or other financial institutions, as w( II E other multilateral or bilateral agencies engaged in supporting private sector infrastructure prclects, to be invited into discussions related to project prepara or optimal approaches to financial structuring, and the design and use of risk instruments, with a view to ensure suitability of projects for commercial and/or institutional investment. 3.2 A GIF Governing Cc uncil is proposed to oversee the GIF's strategic programmin] management and use of funcs, and development of operational policies and procedures; E:1 hold the GIF Management Unit (see section 4.1) accountable for delivering on the facility's objectives and principles, with advice and support from the Advisory Partners. The compo i io i of the Governing Council will be agreed between IBRD and prospective partners, but is propE e: to comprise representatives of Funding and Technical Partners. 3.3 An Advisory Counc I comprised of all GIF partners, chaired by the Managing Din c tc and Chief Financial Officer ol the World Bank Group, will be periodically convened to facili a:E coordination of GIF activities and support GIF operations. This Advisory Council will serve :a sounding board, providing gu dance and support for GIF Management, and in particular wi I ii view to ensuring suitability of projects for private sector investment. 4 Management 4.1 The GIF will be admi iistered by the World Bank Group, through a small, dedicatel m established for this purpose (:he GIF Management Unit). The GIF Management Unit will fL -i:1i n as a coordinating body as projects are identified for inclusion in the pipeline, and then mo% v toward technical support and financing phases. The GIF Management Unit will not lead in( i i: jal projects. 4.2 GIF activity implementation teams will be led by selected staff of Technical Partne institutions, coordinated by tle GIF Management Unit in consultation with client governme rs according to specific project iequirements and the project origination processes. Compos Ii:r of the implementation teams may vary according to the need of individual projects and gove nIn nts. 5 Activities and Projects 5.1 Project selection criteria and processes could be developed to reflect the follow i'g principles: (i) Development Inipact-projects that support the development goals of the GI" partner institutions; (ii) Alignment-pro ects that are aligned with recipient/sponsor country prior ties a-: strategies; (iii) Complexity-pr)jects that require multiple parties to come together to provid structuring, arrar ging and financial support, and/or projects which require a bI . Id of financial instrum mts; and 8
ï»¿Execution Version (iv) Catalytic impac:-projects that have significant potential to achieve financial / I ility, leverage public f inds, and attract private sector and/or institutional investors- s u: 1 as through Public-Private Partnership (PPP) modalities-while still meeting government's se vice delivery objectives. The GIF will focus on infrastr icture investments that have global public good characteristic E, ; ich as climate friendly-project; that are low emitting or encourage efficiency in the provisior :1 infrastructure services; and tiade enabling-projects that facilitate or enhance interconne:Ji. y and trade. 5.2 The scope of suppcrt provided to a particular project will be defined flexibly, with E v 3w to complementing the resourl.es and support already available from partner entities and oi 1 funding mechanisms. During the GIF pilot phase, this support may include the following ac li sil, corresponding to major proje.t development stages: (i) Project definition and enabling environment - sector planning and investment prioritization; pro ect definition, including needs analysis and pre-feasibility scr : i g; and legal, regula:ory, or institutional reforms; (ii) Project preparati >n and investment feasibility - feasibility studies, investment appraisal, and PPP structuring; (iii) Transaction supfort and financial structuring - preparing and implementing transactions, anc design of risk mitigation/credit enhancement packages; and (iv) Financial arrangi ig and credit enhancement - arranging and mobilizing financ 1; packages from a range of sources and partners. 6 Operational Policies Sound operational policies- ncluding in particular the management of environmental and ;:(: al impacts and risks, and transr arency in procurement-are critical to the success of infrastr ct. e projects in supporting sustair able, inclusive development; as well as for investors in those projects to manage financial, reputational and legal risks. In developing the appropriate framework for GIF-supported operations, the GIF could draw upon existing arrangements cr external implementing entitie; under World Bank Partnership Programs. GIF partners will collaborate to establish an ar proach to fiduciary, environmental and social safeguards an( )t er standards and policies, and cevelop, manage and oversee an accreditation process for GP Technical Partners who are expected to function as implementing entities for GIF activities 9
ï»¿Execution Version Annex 2 Multilateral Development Banks (MDBs) and their Respectiv e Project Preparation Resources and Initiatives During the process of finalizing the design of the GIF, the following MDBs will be invited to partic p as initial Technical Partners. The operational details for the GIF will at all times complement the :<i :ing efforts and facilities of these MDB3, which include but are not limited to the infrastructure pr: iect preparation resources and initiatives isted below: a. Asian Development Bank (ADB) - Office of Public-Private Partnership and its p ':p: sed Asia Pacific Project Preparation Facility ('AP3F') as well as several dedicated 'ti )nal PPFs; c. European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) - Legal Ti -i! :ion Programme, and the proposed EBRD Infrastructure Project Preparation Facility ('I I '); d. European Investment Bank (EIB) - European PPP Expertise Centre (EPEC); e. Inter-American Development Bank (IADB) - 'InfraFund' project preparation facil 1:; f. Islamic Developme it Bank (IsDB) - Arab Financing Facility for Infrastructure Tr ical Assistance Facility (!FFI TAF), co-managed with the International Finance Cor:l r: tion (IFC); and g.
